47394.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Refers to the titled sutta “Unprofitable” in the Saṃyutta Nikāya, discussing the theme of non‑merit.

42044.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The term denotes the Sutta concerning the earth, literally “earth discourse,” found in Saṃyutta Nikāya 15.

33418.meaning_1: the second discourse on the aggregates
33418.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
It denotes the second discourse on the aggregates within the Saṃyutta Nikāya, literally “the second aggregate discourse.”

42522.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Refers to the mountain sutta (SN 15.5), a discourse concerning mountains.

33305.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the Saṃyutta Nikāya this is the second sutta dealing with a mountain discourse, used here to list the sutras of that collection.

1527.meaning_1: ascetics, priests and wanderers of other religions
1527.sutta_1: “evameva kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa diṭṭhisampannassa puggalassa adhigamaṃ upanidhāya aññatitthiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇaparibbājakānaṃ adhigamo neva satimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na sahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti na satasahassimaṃ kalaṃ upeti.
1527.example_1: “In the same way, compared with the achievements of a noble disciple accomplished in view, the achievements of the ascetics, brahmins, and wanderers of other religions is not nearly a hundredth, a thousandth, or a hundred thousandth part.

51741.meaning_1: having great achievement; of enormous attainment
51741.sutta_1: evaṃ mahādhigamo, bhikkhave, diṭṭhisampanno puggalo, evaṃ mahābhiñño”ti.
51741.example_1: So great is the achievement of the individual accomplished in view, so great is their direct knowledge.”

51848.meaning_1: with powerful direct knowledge; having substantial realization
51848.sutta_1: evaṃ mahādhigamo, bhikkhave, diṭṭhisampanno puggalo, evaṃ mahābhiñño”ti.
51848.example_1: So great is the achievement of the individual accomplished in view, so great is their direct knowledge.”

35055.meaning_1: discourse on non‑attachment to the elements
35055.meaning_lit: the sutta of non‑attachment to dhātu
35055.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-oss-120b:free
The term refers to the sutta (teaching) that deals with the practice of non‑attachment (nānatta) toward the twelve dhātus (elements).

47656.meaning_1: the discourse on contact (phassa) and non‑self (anatta)
47656.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-oss-120b:free
phassanānattasutta is a three‑member kammadhāraya compound: phassa “contact”, anatta “non‑self”, and sutta “discourse”. It appears as the title of a sutta in the Dhātusaṃyutta (SN 14), hence the meaning “the discourse on contact and non‑self”.

38910.trans: Discourse on the non‑self of the sense bases
38910.meaning_1: the sutta dealing with the doctrine that the sense‑bases (phassa) are not‑self
38910.meaning_lit: the discourse of non‑self of sense‑contact
38910.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-oss-120b:free
nophassanānattasutta is a negative compound (na‑) formed from phassa “sense‑contact” and anatta “non‑self”, followed by sutta “discourse”. It appears in SN 14.3 and introduces the teaching that the sense bases are not‑self.

70254.meaning_1: the sutta on the non‑self of feeling
70254.comment:
openrouter: openai/gpt-oss-120b:free
The compound combines vedanā “feeling” with anānatta “non‑self”, indicating that this sutta treats feeling as an anatta characteristic.

33496.meaning_lit: the second sutta about diversity of feeling
33496.comment:
openrouter: google/gemini-2.0-flash-exp:free
The sutta discusses the diversity of feelings (vedanā) and is the second sutta with this name in the Dhatusamyutta of the Samyutta Nikaya. The meaning is derived from the name of the sutta itself and its context within the Samyutta Nikaya.

48350.meaning_1: Sutta on the difference of external elements
48350.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
This is a sutta within the Saṃyutta Nikāya, specifically in the section dealing with elements (dhātu). The name indicates it discusses the differences or variations (nānattā) pertaining to external (bāhira) elements. In the provided contextual sentence, it is listed as part of the dhātusaṃyuttaṃ, reinforcing its theme.

57415.meaning_1: sutta on the diversity of perceptions
57415.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
This entry refers to a sutta from the Saṃyutta Nikāya which deals with the variety or diversity (anatta) of perceptions (saññā). The contextual sentence "SN14.7 dhātusaṃyuttaṃ, saññānānattasuttaṃ 7. saññānānattasuttaṃ" indicates its position within the Dhātu Saṃyutta (Discourse on Elements) and its title. The meaning "sutta on the diversity of perceptions" accurately reflects the compound nature of the word.

55183.meaning_1: desire for forms; interest in forms
55183.meaning_2: desire for sights; interest in sights
55183.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
In the contextual sentence, rūpacchando is translated as "desire for sights". This follows from the preceding term rūpasaṅkappaṃ (thoughts about sights) and leads to the subsequent term rūpapariḷāho (passion for sights). Therefore, it signifies an active wanting or eagerness for sensory experiences.
55183.sutta_1: rūpadhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaññā, rūpasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaṅkappo, rūpasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpacchando, rūpacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariḷāho, rūpapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariyesanā …pe…
55183.example_1: The sight element gives rise to the perception of sights. The perception of sights gives rise to thoughts about sights. Thoughts about sights give rise to the desire for sights. The desire for sights gives rise to the passion for sights. The passion for sights gives rise to searching for sights. …

55210.meaning_1: quest for forms; search for sights
55210.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage the term refers to “searching for sights”, i.e. the mental activity of seeking visual objects, which follows the desire for sights and leads to gaining them.
55210.sutta_1: rūpadhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaññā, rūpasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaṅkappo, rūpasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasamphasso, rūpasamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasamphassajā vedanā, rūpasamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpacchando, rūpacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariḷāho, rūpapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariyesanā, rūpapariyesanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpalābho …pe…
55210.example_1: The sight element gives rise to the perception of sights. The perception of sights gives rise to thoughts about sights. Thoughts about sights give rise to sight contact. Sight contact gives rise to feeling born of sight contact. Feeling born of sight contact gives rise to the desire for sights. The desire for sights gives rise to the passion for sights. The passion for sights gives rise to searching for sights. Searching for sights gives rise to gaining sights …

34850.meaning_1: thought about mental phenomena; conception of thoughts
34850.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
In the context of sn14.7:3.2, 'dhammasaṅkappo' refers to the 'thoughts about ideas' or 'conception of thoughts' that arise after the perception of ideas ('dhammasaññā'). It signifies a deeper engagement with the understanding of phenomena.
34850.sutta_1: dhammadhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaññā, dhammasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaṅkappo, dhammasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammacchando, dhammacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariḷāho, dhammapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariyesanā.
34850.example_1: The idea element gives rise to the perception of ideas. The perception of ideas gives rise to thoughts about ideas. Thoughts about ideas give rise to the desire for ideas. The desire for ideas gives rise to the passion for ideas. The passion for ideas gives rise to searching for ideas.

34797.meaning_1: fever for mental phenomena; burning passion for thoughts
34797.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
In the given contextual sentence, dhammapariḷāha refers to an intense desire or burning passion for understanding and engaging with phenomena (dhamma). It is the stage that follows the desire for ideas (dhammacchanda) and precedes the search for ideas (dhammapariyesanā). It highlights a state of fervent mental engagement with concepts.
34797.sutta_1: dhammadhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaññā, dhammasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaṅkappo, dhammasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammacchando, dhammacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariḷāho, dhammapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariyesanā.
34797.example_1: The idea element gives rise to the perception of ideas. The perception of ideas gives rise to thoughts about ideas. Thoughts about ideas give rise to the desire for ideas. The desire for ideas gives rise to the passion for ideas. The passion for ideas gives rise to searching for ideas.

34795.meaning_1: searching for phenomena; seeking ideas; seeking the Dhamma
34795.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
In the given contextual sentence, dhammapariyesanā is understood as "searching for ideas" or "seeking the Dhamma" as a result of previous stages of mental activity: desire for ideas, thoughts about ideas, and perception of ideas. The translation provided in the text, "searching for ideas," directly reflects this progression.
34795.sutta_1: dhammadhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaññā, dhammasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaṅkappo, dhammasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammacchando, dhammacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariḷāho, dhammapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariyesanā.
34795.example_1: The idea element gives rise to the perception of ideas. The perception of ideas gives rise to thoughts about ideas. Thoughts about ideas give rise to the desire for ideas. The desire for ideas gives rise to the passion for ideas. The passion for ideas gives rise to searching for ideas.

38905.meaning_1: Sutta not to be sought for its diversity; the discourse on the non-diversity of the search.
38905.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
The meaning "Sutta not to be sought for its diversity" indicates that the discourse itself is not to be analyzed based on its varied aspects or interpretations, but rather its core message should be understood. Alternatively, it can mean "the discourse on the non-diversity of the search," implying that the search for something (perhaps the Dhamma) is not to be pursued in a fragmented or diverse manner, but rather through a unified and focused approach.

48352.meaning_1: Sutta on the non-duality of external sensations
48352.compound_construction:
bāhira + phassāna
bāhiraphassāna + anatta
bāhiraphassanānattā + sutta
48352.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
This is the name of a sutta in the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 14.9). The meaning "Sutta on the non-duality of external sensations" is derived from its constituent parts: "bāhira" (external), "phassāna" (sensations, plural accusative of phassa), "anatta" (non-duality, or not other), and "sutta" (discourse). The grammatical analysis indicates it is a neuter compound word.

55250.meaning_1: produced by contact with forms; caused by the impression of sights; born from form experience
55250.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
The contextual sentence shows a clear causal chain: rūpasamphassa (sight contact) leads to rūpasamphassajā vedanā (feeling born from sight contact). This entry correctly captures the meaning derived from this context.
55250.sutta_1: rūpadhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaññā, rūpasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaṅkappo, rūpasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasamphasso, rūpasamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasamphassajā vedanā, rūpasamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpacchando, rūpacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariḷāho, rūpapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariyesanā, rūpapariyesanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpalābho …pe…
55250.example_1: The sight element gives rise to the perception of sights. The perception of sights gives rise to thoughts about sights. Thoughts about sights give rise to sight contact. Sight contact gives rise to feeling born of sight contact. Feeling born of sight contact gives rise to the desire for sights. The desire for sights gives rise to the passion for sights. The passion for sights gives rise to searching for sights. Searching for sights gives rise to gaining sights …

33334.meaning_1: the second sutta on the difference of external contact
33334.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
This entry refers to the second sutta within the Dhātusaṃyutta of the Saṃyutta Nikāya (SN 14.10). The compound word 'dutiyabāhiraphassanānattasutta' translates to 'the second sutta on the difference of external contact'. It signifies a discourse that deals with a second instance or aspect of distinctions related to sensory experiences arising from external objects.

57721.meaning_1: the discourse on the seven elements
57721.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
This entry refers to a specific discourse (sutta) within the Pāḷi canon, likely the Saṃyutta Nikāya. The name "sattadhātusutta" directly translates to "seven-element discourse," indicating its subject matter. In the given contextual sentence, "dhātusaṃyuttaṃ, sattadhātusuttaṃ" places it within the broader section on "groups of elements" (dhātusaṃyutta) and identifies it as the specific sutta "sattadhātusuttaṃ". The meaning "the discourse on the seven elements" accurately reflects this identification.

57840.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
This entry combines the cardinal number "satta" (seven) with the demonstrative pronoun "imā" (these, feminine plural nominative). The contextual sentence clearly uses it to refer to "these seven elements".

12013.meaning_1: state of radiance; element of luminosity
12013.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
This entry refers to the "element of luminosity" as seen in the contextual sentence from SN 14.11.1.4. It is part of a list of elements or states.
12013.sutta_1: ābhādhātu, subhadhātu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—
12013.example_1: The element of luminosity, the element of beauty, the element of the dimension of infinite space, the element of the dimension of infinite consciousness, the element of the dimension of nothingness, the element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the element of the cessation of perception and feeling.

64232.meaning_1: state of beauty; element of attractiveness
64232.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
In the contextual sentence, 'subhadhātu' is listed alongside other 'dhātu' (elements/states) within the framework of Buddhist cosmology and meditation states. It signifies the 'element of beauty' or the 'state of attractiveness', likely referring to a perceptual quality or a subjective experience of pleasantness.
64232.sutta_1: ābhādhātu, subhadhātu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—
64232.example_1: The element of luminosity, the element of beauty, the element of the dimension of infinite space, the element of the dimension of infinite consciousness, the element of the dimension of nothingness, the element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the element of the cessation of perception and feeling.

11063.meaning_1: state of the dimension of infinite space; element of the base of infinity of space
11063.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
This term refers to one of the eight bases of attainment (aṭṭhasamāpatti) in Buddhist meditation. It is a state associated with the third formless attainment (arūpa-samāpatti), where the meditator experiences the dimension of infinite space. The contextual sentence lists it among other states of consciousness or elements, highlighting its place within a broader classification of spiritual attainments or constituents of experience.
11063.sutta_1: ābhādhātu, subhadhātu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—
11063.example_1: The element of luminosity, the element of beauty, the element of the dimension of infinite space, the element of the dimension of infinite consciousness, the element of the dimension of nothingness, the element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the element of the cessation of perception and feeling.

67704.meaning_1: state of the dimension of infinite consciousness; element of the dimension of infinite consciousness
67704.comment:
gemini: gemini-2.5-flash-lite
In the context of the suttanta, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu refers to the fourth of the formless attainments (arūpa-samāpatti), characterized by the realization of infinite consciousness. It is presented as a "state" or "element" within a list of such states or elements.
67704.sutta_1: ābhādhātu, subhadhātu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—
67704.example_1: The element of luminosity, the element of beauty, the element of the dimension of infinite space, the element of the dimension of infinite consciousness, the element of the dimension of nothingness, the element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the element of the cessation of perception and feeling.

55234.meaning_1: thought about forms; conception of sights
55234.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage rūpasaṅkappa denotes the mental conception of visual forms that gives rise to desire and passion.
55234.sutta_1: rūpadhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaññā, rūpasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaṅkappo, rūpasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpacchando, rūpacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariḷāho, rūpapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariyesanā …pe…
55234.example_1: The sight element gives rise to the perception of sights. The perception of sights gives rise to thoughts about sights. Thoughts about sights give rise to the desire for sights. The desire for sights gives rise to the passion for sights. The passion for sights gives rise to searching for sights. …

34698.meaning_1: interest in mental phenomena; desire for thoughts
34698.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited passage dhammacchando denotes the craving for ideas that arises after perception, illustrating how a mental propensity can condition further affective and volitional states.
34698.sutta_1: dhammadhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaññā, dhammasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaṅkappo, dhammasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammacchando, dhammacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariḷāho, dhammapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariyesanā.
34698.example_1: The idea element gives rise to the perception of ideas. The perception of ideas gives rise to thoughts about ideas. Thoughts about ideas give rise to the desire for ideas. The desire for ideas gives rise to the passion for ideas. The passion for ideas gives rise to searching for ideas.

34870.meaning_1: produced by contact with mental phenomena; caused by the impression of thoughts; born from phenomenal experience
34870.comment:
openrouter: upstage/solar-pro-3:free
In the dependent origination chain (sn14.9), dhammasamphassaja marks the feeling (vedanā) arising specifically from mental contact (samphassa) with dhamma. It exemplifies how conditioned feeling is generated through interaction with phenomena, a key insight into the mental origination process.
34870.sutta_1: dhammadhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaññā, dhammasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaṅkappo, dhammasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasamphasso, dhammasamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasamphassajā vedanā, dhammasamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammacchando, dhammacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariḷāho, dhammapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariyesanā, dhammapariyesanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammalābho.
34870.example_1: The idea element gives rise to the perception of ideas. The perception of ideas gives rise to thoughts about ideas. Thoughts about ideas give rise to idea contact. Idea contact gives rise to feeling born of idea contact. Feeling born of idea contact gives rise to the desire for ideas. The desire for ideas gives rise to the passion for ideas. The passion for ideas gives rise to searching for ideas. Searching for ideas gives rise to gaining ideas.

11080.meaning_1: state of the dimension of nothingness; element of the sphere of emptiness

related_words.meaning_1: unskilful state
with various states; having numerous elements
state of goodwill
deathless state; immortality; epithet of Nibbāna
formless state; immaterial element
unconditioned state; unconstructed element
state of ignorance; ignorant condition
state of non-harm; state of non-cruelty
space; space element
dependent on the dimension of nothingness; based on the sphere of emptiness
connected with the dimension of nothingness; concerned with the base of nothingness
recognition of dimension of nothingness; perception of dimension of nothingness (in)
aware of dimension of nothingness; percipient of dimension of nothingness (in)
beneficial for the dimension of nothingness; supportive for the base of nothingness
attainment of the dimension of nothingness; attainment of the sphere of emptiness
connection with the dimension of nothingness; concern with the base of nothingness
refined and true perception of the dimension of nothingness
with a refined and true perception of the dimension of nothingness
intent on the dimension of nothingness; fixed on the base of nothingness
gone to the dimension of nothingness; epithet of a class of devas

11080.comment:
openrouter: upstage/solar-pro-3:free
In sn14.11:1.4 the term denotes the fifth dhātu – the “dimension of nothingness”, an immaterial sphere where perception ceases, representing the base of emptiness beyond the other six elements.
11080.sutta_1: ābhādhātu, subhadhātu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—
11080.example_1: The element of luminosity, the element of beauty, the element of the dimension of infinite space, the element of the dimension of infinite consciousness, the element of the dimension of nothingness, the element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the element of the cessation of perception and feeling.

38843.meaning_1: state of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception; element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception
38843.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the cited passage it denotes the element of the dimension of neither perception nor non‑perception, a higher meditative state.
38843.sutta_1: ābhādhātu, subhadhātu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—
38843.example_1: The element of luminosity, the element of beauty, the element of the dimension of infinite space, the element of the dimension of infinite consciousness, the element of the dimension of nothingness, the element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the element of the cessation of perception and feeling.

57461.meaning_1: element of the cessation of perception and feeling
57461.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
This term denotes the mental element marking the ending of perception and feeling, i.e., the cessation of perception and feeling, as listed among the dhātus in the passage.
57461.sutta_1: ābhādhātu, subhadhātu, ākāsānañcāyatanadhātu, viññāṇañcāyatanadhātu, ākiñcaññāyatanadhātu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu, saññāvedayitanirodhadhātu—
57461.example_1: The element of luminosity, the element of beauty, the element of the dimension of infinite space, the element of the dimension of infinite consciousness, the element of the dimension of nothingness, the element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, and the element of the cessation of perception and feeling.

56814.meaning_1: meditation attainment with a residue of volitional formations
56814.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In this context it denotes the meditative attainment of the dimension “neither perception nor non‑perception” wherein some volitional formations remain, i.e., a state with a residue of conditioned phenomena.
56814.sutta_1: yāyaṃ, bhikkhu, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanadhātu—ayaṃ dhātu saṅkhārāvasesasamāpatti pattabbā.
56814.example_1: The element of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception is an attainment with residual conditioned phenomena.

58142.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
Refers to the Saṃyutta Nikāya 14 sutta dealing with meetings, literally “meeting discourse”.

48844.meaning_1: interest in ill-will; desire for malice
48844.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
The word expresses a mental inclination toward malice, serving as the basis for the chain of unwholesome mental states described in the passage.
48844.sutta_1: byāpādadhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati byāpādasaññā, byāpādasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati byāpādasaṅkappo …pe… byāpādacchando … byāpādapariḷāho … byāpādapariyesanā …
48844.example_1: The element of malice gives rise to malicious perceptions. Malicious perceptions give rise to malicious thoughts. … malicious desires … malicious passions … malicious searches …

48853.meaning_1: fever for ill-will; burning passion for dislike
48853.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the context (SN 14.12) it denotes a burning passion of ill‑will that gives rise to malicious perceptions, thoughts and desires.
48853.sutta_1: byāpādadhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati byāpādasaññā, byāpādasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati byāpādasaṅkappo …pe… byāpādacchando … byāpādapariḷāho … byāpādapariyesanā …
48853.example_1: The element of malice gives rise to malicious perceptions. Malicious perceptions give rise to malicious thoughts. … malicious desires … malicious passions … malicious searches …

48852.meaning_1: quest for ill-will; search for dislike
48852.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage it denotes the final stage of actively seeking ill‑will among the listed negative mental states.
48852.sutta_1: byāpādadhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati byāpādasaññā, byāpādasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati byāpādasaṅkappo …pe… byāpādacchando … byāpādapariḷāho … byāpādapariyesanā …
48852.example_1: The element of malice gives rise to malicious perceptions. Malicious perceptions give rise to malicious thoughts. … malicious desires … malicious passions … malicious searches …

69731.meaning_1: interest in harming; desire for cruelty
69731.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the passage, vihiṃsāchanda denotes the mental propensity toward cruelty that follows cruel perceptions, giving rise to cruel desires and passions.
69731.sutta_1: vihiṃsādhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati vihiṃsāsaññā; vihiṃsāsaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vihiṃsāsaṅkappo …pe… vihiṃsāchando … vihiṃsāpariḷāho … vihiṃsāpariyesanā …
69731.example_1: The element of cruelty gives rise to cruel perceptions. Cruel perceptions give rise to cruel thoughts. … cruel desires … cruel passions … cruel searches …

69734.meaning_1: fever for harming; burning passion for cruelty
69734.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the quoted passage it denotes the intense, burning passion for cruelty that gives rise to cruel perceptions, thoughts, desires and passions.
69734.sutta_1: vihiṃsādhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati vihiṃsāsaññā; vihiṃsāsaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vihiṃsāsaṅkappo …pe… vihiṃsāchando … vihiṃsāpariḷāho … vihiṃsāpariyesanā …
69734.example_1: The element of cruelty gives rise to cruel perceptions. Cruel perceptions give rise to cruel thoughts. … cruel desires … cruel passions … cruel searches …

69733.meaning_1: quest for harming; search for cruelty
69733.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the quoted passage it denotes the culmination of the mental process, actively seeking cruelty.
69733.sutta_1: vihiṃsādhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati vihiṃsāsaññā; vihiṃsāsaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vihiṃsāsaṅkappo …pe… vihiṃsāchando … vihiṃsāpariḷāho … vihiṃsāpariyesanā …
69733.example_1: The element of cruelty gives rise to cruel perceptions. Cruel perceptions give rise to cruel thoughts. … cruel desires … cruel passions … cruel searches …

30511.meaning_1: living in the grass and wood
30511.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In the given sentence, tiṇakaṭṭhanissita refers to beings that dwell in the grass and wood, i.e., those living among such vegetation.
30511.sutta_1: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso ādittaṃ tiṇukkaṃ sukkhe tiṇadāye nikkhipeyya; no ce hatthehi ca pādehi ca khippameva nibbāpeyya. evañhi, bhikkhave, ye tiṇakaṭṭhanissitā pāṇā te anayabyasanaṃ āpajjeyyuṃ.
30511.example_1: Suppose a person was to drop a burning torch in a thicket of dry grass. If they don’t quickly extinguish it with their hands and feet, the creatures living in the grass and wood would come to ruin.

38709.meaning_1: interest in renunciation; desire to give up sensual pleasure
38709.comment:
openrouter: nvidia/nemotron-3-nano-30b-a3b:free
In this context it expresses the enthusiasm that arises after thoughts of renunciation, reflecting a desire to abandon sensual pleasures.
38709.example_1: Thoughts of renunciation give rise to enthusiasm for renunciation.
